titleStmt.title: Cues to action, perceived risk, perceived bene ts, perceived obstacles and executed safety behavior of preventing monkeypox infection among PLWH : a structural equation model

funder.orgName: "The Joint Guidance Project of Science and Technology of Qiqihar

affiliation.orgName: Heilongjiang Center for Disease Control and Prevention
Heilongjiang Center for Disease Control and Prevention Ronghuang Guo Qiqihar Medical University

analytic.title: Cues to action, perceived risk, perceived bene ts, perceived obstacles and executed safety behavior of preventing monkeypox infection among PLWH : a structural equation model

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Background
div.p: Between June and August, there was an increase in monkeypox cases in China, and the mortality rate (7%) caused by monkeypox infection among people living with HIV(PLWH) is higher than that of the general population. It is particularly important for PLWH to adopt healthy behaviors to prevent monkeypox infection. Health education activities to prevent infection have been carried out through various channels, but we know very little about the prevention and control behaviors adopted by PLWH.

div.head: Methods
div.p: The subjects of this cross-sectional study included 467 PLWHs from Heilongjiang Province, China. The questionnaire was collected through Questionnaire Star from August 11 to September 10, 2023, including general sociological data, cues to action(CA), perceived risk (PR), perceived benefits(PB), perceived obstacles(PO) and executed safety behavior(ESB) data. The effects of CA on PR, PB, PO, and ESB were calculated using a structural equation model, as well as the effects of PR, PB, and PO on ESB. We also calculated the intermediate effects of PR, PB, and PO between CA and ESB.

div.head: Results
div.p: There were statistically significant differences (P < 0.05) in gender, marital status, sexual orientation, fixed sexual partner, receiving HIV related treatment, heard of monkeypox, more accurate channels for obtaining information, more willing to access information channels, the most satisfactory channel for obtaining information and monkeypox cognition. There weren't statistically significant differences (P > 0.05) in education level and occupation. The structural equation indicates that cues to action(CA) was predictive factors for perceived risk (PR), perceived benefits(PB), perceived obstacles(PO) and executed safety behavior(ESB) (P < 0.001).

Perceived risk (PR), perceived benefits(PB) and perceived obstacles(PO) were predictive factors for the executed safety behavior(ESB) (P < 0.01). PR played a mediating role of 33.99% between CA and ESB. PO played a mediating role of 6.9% between CA and ESB. PB didn't play a mediating role between CA and ESB.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This study indicates that preventing monkeypox behaviors among PLWH is better, but there is still a gap between correctly implementing preventive behavior by everyone. CA, PR, PB, and PO are predictive factors for ESB. PR and PO play a mediating role between CA and ESB. Therefore, increasing CA, PR, and PB, and reducing PO can be used to improve the ESB of monkeypox among PLWH.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Monkeypox is a zoonotic disease caused by the monkeypox virus (MPXV) [1,2]. The frequency and geographical distribution of cases have mainly been concentrated across West and Central Africa in the past [3,4]. Over the past few decades, the steady increase in monkeypox cases in Africa has been ignored by the global scientific community until last year [5]. Since the first discovery of monkeypox cases in the UK in May 2022 [6], many countries have reported confirmed cases of monkeypox [7,8,9]. As of May 30, 2023, 111 countries worldwide have reported 87858 cases of monkeypox and 143 deaths [10]. Due to the increasing number of confirmed cases globally, the World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the monkeypox outbreak as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on July 23, 2022 [11,12,13].

Currently, monkeypox is mainly transmitted through respiratory droplets, infectious agents, and direct contact with infected individuals [14]. Recent analysis has found that sexual transmission is the main route of transmission, mostly in males having sex with males subjects [15,16]. Since the first confirmed case of imported monkeypox was reported in mainland China (excluding Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan) in September 2022 [3,17], Local monkeypox outbreak starting in June 2023 [18]. From June to August 2023, there have been relatively high reports of confirmed cases, with 106 new confirmed cases of monkeypox reported in June [19], 491 new confirmed cases reported in July [20], and 501 new confirmed cases reported in August [21]. Among the 992 cases reported in July and August, only 5 were female (5/992), and the rest were male [19,20]. And the most of the population is clearly male sexual behavior [20,21].Many reports suggest that high-risk sexual behavior of unprotected sexual contact is a potential risk factor [16,22].

During the outbreak in 2022, the mortality rate caused by monkeypox infection remained below 0.1% [23,24]， but the mortality rate caused by monkeypox infection among people living with HIV (PLWH) is 7% [16]. PLWH had accounted for 38-50% of patients diagnosed with monkeypox in the 2022 multicountry mpox outbreak [16]. Cisgender men who have sex with men (MSM) and PLWH are disproportionately impacted among the monkeypox outbreak [25,26]. MSM behavior and high-risk sexual behavior may be risk factors for monkeypox transmission [27,28]. In view of the increasing number of case reports in Chinese Mainland in July, experts analyzed that it may be related to the hidden transmission of monkeypox epidemic among MSM, and suggested doing a good job in identifying and self monitoring monkeypox to avoid infection [29]. On May 10, 2023, although the monkeypox is no longer as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern of the WHO [30]. But in August, the reported cases of monkeypox continued to increase despite not decreasing.

Due to the hidden transmission characteristics of monkeypox [29], the monkeypox epidemic and prevention knowledge have been transmitted through various channels such as traditional (such as Television, Newspapers, and Radio), new Media channels (such as the Internet, WeChat) and professional channels (such as Communities and Hospitals). However, the number of PLWH with monkeypox is still high [25]. The health belief model (HBM) is widely used to predict health-related behaviors [31,32,33]. We referred to the theory of HBM and used the characteristics

div.head: Samples
div.p: We conducted a cross-sectional anonymous online survey from August 11 to September 10, 2023, using electronic questionnaires distributed on online social media platforms (WeChat and QQ) among PLWH. When PLWH came for antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs or physical examinations, they scanned the QR code of the questionnaire and then fill it out. At the same time, we also used the snowball method to disseminate and distribute questionnaires in PLWH.

In this study, the inclusion criteria were: (1) Age ≥ 18 years old; (2) HIV infected individuals; (3) Volunteered to participate. According to these standards, a total of 467 people participated in this study.

div.head: Questionnaire
div.p: The questionnaire consists of the following parts: (1) Sociodemographic prediction variables, including age, gender, marital status, education level, occupation, sexual orientation, fixed sexual partner, receiving HIV related treatment, infected with monkeypox ever or currently, heard of monkeypox, more accurate channels for obtaining information, more willing to access information channels, the most satisfactory channel for obtaining information and monkeypox cognition.

(2)Cognition of monkeypox. (3)Cues to action(CA), perceived risk (PR), perceived benefits(PB), perceived obstacles(PO) and executed safety behavior(ESB) for preventing monkeypox infection (see Table 1 for details). The questionnaire includes 37 questions, which are usually completed in less than 10 minutes.

div.head: Table 1. CA, PR, PB, PO and ESB
Research Constructs
div.p: Measurement Items

div.head: CA
div.p: The recently released monkeypox epidemic, such as the number of infected individuals, the characteristics of the infected population, and the characteristics of the deaths caused by infection, reminds me to take measures to prevent monkeypox infection. The government suggested that I take measures to prevent monkeypox infection. Professionals suggest that I take measures to prevent monkeypox infection.

div.head: PR
div.p: Monkeypox can pose a threat to my health. I am easily infected with monkeypox.
After monkeypox infection, the consequences are very serious. Monkeypox can worsen my current disease condition.

div.head: PB
div.p: Timely understanding of monkeypox epidemic information has improved my awareness of preventing monkeypox infection.
Learning knowledge related to monkeypox has improved my ability to judge the prevalence of monkeypox. Actively taking preventive measures to reduce my risk of contracting monkeypox.

div.head: PO
div.p: Knowledge related to monkeypox is difficult to master and apply.
Observing whether others and myself suffer from monkeypox increases my psychological stress.
Taking preventive measures has affected my relationship with others.

div.head: ESB
div.p: I have learned knowledge and information related to monkeypox. I observed the condition of monkeypox in myself and those around me. I have executed safe behavior for monkeypox prevention，For example, wearing a condom during sexual activity.

div.head: Variables and Measurements
div.p: CA, PR, PB, PO and ESB were scored on a 5-point Likert scale, with a score of 5 indicating strong agreement and a score of 1 indicating strong disagreement .

div.head: Reliability of the Questionnaire
div.p: Cronbach's alpha internal reliability method provided a figure of 0.890 for the internal consistency of our research, Cronbach's alpha of PR was 0.834, Cronbach's alpha of PB was 0.964, Cronbach's alpha of PO was 0.842, Cronbach's alpha of CA was 0.966, and Cronbach's alpha of ESB was 0.927, indicating that the research tool was effective and reliable for data collection activities.

div.head: Statistical Analysis
div.p: Statistical analysis was conducted using SPSS 23.0 and AMOS 20.0 software packages.
Descriptive data was calculated, correlated, and modeled using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM). A p-value of < 0.05 is considered statistically significant.

div.head: ESB and Participant Characteristics
div.p: A total of 467 PLWH were enrolled in this study. The average age of the participants was 42.34 years (SD = 13.46). Among the participants, most individuals (94.6%) were male, most individuals (48.1%) were of unmarried, most of them (42.0%) were from middle school or below, most of them (98.5%) were non medical related professions, many had a same-sex sexual orientation (57.6%) and had no fixed sexual partner (68.7%), everyone receives ART treatment (100.0%) and doesn't infected with monkeypox ever or currently(100.0%), 82.7% of participants had heard of monkeypox, 43.4% of participants believed that more accurate channels for obtaining information was professional channels, 40.5% of participants believed that more willing to access information channels was professional channels, 45.4% of participants believed that the most satisfactory channel for obtaining information was professional channels, and 40% of participants' score were 4 or less (see Tables 2 for details).

div.head: The SEM Fitting Index Results
div.p: The final model showed a good model fit: χ2/DF=3.549, RMSEA=0.074, TLI=0.963, CFI=0.970 and IFI=0.970 [34,35].

div.head: Model Analysis Results
div.p: The path analysis results indicate that CA had a significant positive impact on PR, PB and ESB.
CA had a significantly negative effect on PO. PR and PB had a significant positive impact on ESB.

PO had a significantly negative effect on ESB. The results of paths are shown in Fig. 2. As shown in Table 3, PB had no mediating effect between CA on ESB, PO played a 6.9% mediating role between CA on ESB, and PR played a 33.99% mediating role between CA on ESB(see Tables 3 for details).
Table 3. Mediating effect test.

Note: IV = independent variable; M = mediator; DV = dependent variable. Our findings showed that the healthy behavior of female PLWH in preventing monkeypox is better than that of male, and the difference is statistically significant (P<0.05). Similar findings have been observed in other studies, indicating that women take more preventive measures than men [36]. There is also a statistically significant difference (P<0.001) in the adoption of safe behaviors to prevent monkeypox among different marital states, and the order of scores from highest to lowest is widowed, married, unmarried, and divorced. There is no statistical difference (P>0.05) in the adoption of preventive behavior among different levels of education and professions. No research has been found on the relationship between marital status and monkeypox prevention behavior. This may be related to the less attention paid to monkeypox in recent years [5]. Previous research on the relationship between marital states, occupation, education level, and monkeypox had focused more on knowledge of monkeypox, and less on preventive behavior [37,38]. There is a statistically significant difference (P<0.001) in the prevention of monkeypox behavior among PLWH with different sexual orientations, and the order of scores from highest to lowest is bisexual, opposite sex and same-sex. The score of PLWH with a fixed sexual partner is higher than that with out a fixed sexual partner, and the difference is statistically significant (P<0.01). There is limited research on the correlation between sexual orientation, fixed sexual partner and monkeypox prevention behavior, but previous studies have confirmed a significant correlation between sexual orientation, fixed sexual partner and monkeypox infection [39]. Every PLWH has received ART related treatment and doesn't infect with monkeypox ever or currently. PLWH scores of those who have heard of monkeypox are higher than those who have not, and the difference is statistically significant (P<0.01). For the project of more accurate channels for obtaining information, professional channels (such as communities and hospitals) have the highest scores for monkeypox prevention behavior among PLWH, followed by traditional media channels(such as television, newspapers, and radio), and new media channels(such as the internet, WeChat) has the least, with statistically significant differences(P<0.001). For the project of more willing to access information channels, professional channels (such as communities and hospitals) have the highest scores for monkeypox prevention behavior among PLWH, followed by traditional media channels (such as television, newspapers, and radio), and new media channels (such as the internet, WeChat) has the least, with statistically significant differences (P<0.001). For the project of the most satisfactory channel for obtaining information, professional channels (such as communities and hospitals) have the highest scores for monkeypox prevention behavior among PLWH, followed by traditional media channels(such as television, newspapers, and radio), and new media channels(such as the internet, WeChat) has the least, with statistically significant differences (P<0.001). Different cognitive states of monkeypox lead to different prevention behaviors. The higher the score, the better the prevention behavior, and the difference is statistically significant (P<0.01). There is limited research on the correlation between health education channels, cognition, and monkeypox prevention behavior, which may be related to the lack of attention paid to monkeypox in recent years [5].

As hypothesized, we found that cues to action of the recent increase in monkeypox infection cases and the higher mortality rate among PLWH than other populations had a positive impact on perceived risk. The study results indicated that cues to action of the recent increase in monkeypox infection cases and the higher mortality rate among PLWH than other populations had a positive impact on perceived benefits. Our study showed that cues to action of the recent increase in monkeypox infection cases and the higher mortality rate among PLWH than other populations had a negative impact on perceived obstacles. Until the outbreak of monkeypox in 2022, monkeypox once again caught people's attention. The epidemiological survey shows that the proportion of PLWH infected with monkeypox is higher than that of the general population, and the mortality rate is higher than that of other populations [5,16,23,24]. Cues to action of the recent increase in monkeypox infection cases and the higher mortality rate among PLWH than other populations had a positive impact on executed safety behavior. There is relatively little research on the correlation between action clues and monkeypox prevention behavior, but there is more research on prevention behavior in other diseases, and it has a good positive impact on prevention behavior, which is consistent with the results of this study [40,41]. Perceived risk of monkeypox infection among PLWH had a positive impact on executed safety behavior [42]. Perceived benefits to execute safety behavior among PLWH had a positive impact on executed safety behavior [43].
Perceived obstacles to execute safety behavior among PLWH had a negative impact on executed safety behavior [44].

Our research results indicated that cues to action of the recent increase in monkeypox infection cases and the higher mortality rate among PLWH promoted the implementation of preventive behavior via perceived risk. We found that cues to action regulated ESB via perceived obstacles.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Our study explored several factors (cues to action, perceived risk, perceived benefits, and perceived obstacles) that influence the monkeypox prevention behavior among PLWH. Our findings demonstrated that CA had a significant positive impact on PR, PB and ESB, CA had a significantly negative effect on PO, PR and PB had a significant positive impact on ESB, and PO had a significantly negative effect on ESB. The structural equation model confirmed that the mediating effect of perceived risk and perceived obstacles between cues to action and executed safety behavior. Future intervention measures should focus on improving cues to action, perceived risk, perceived benefits and perceived obstacles to directly or indirectly benefit executed safety behavior for preventing monkeypox infection among PLWH.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: Our research has certain limitations. Firstly, the survey subjects are all from Heilongjiang Province, China, with certain geographical restrictions. Secondly, the research subjects were all voluntary of PLWH, which cannot represent the result of unwillingness to participate in PLWH.

figure.figDesc: of monkeypox infected individuals and professional advice as cues to action(CA) to examine the possible mediating role of multiple executed safety behavior(ESB) indicators between CA and perceived risk (PR) of monkeypox infection, perceived benefits(PB) of adopting safe behavior, perceived obstacles (PO) of adopting safe behavior among PLWH. The research model is shown in Fig. 1.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. Results of paths. Note: ** p<0.01; *** p<0.001.

This study provides evidence to demonstrate the relationship between CA, PR, PB, PO and ESB about monkeypox prevention behavior for PLWH. Therefore, it deepens our understanding of the factors influencing the improvement of monkeypox prevention behavior for PLWH. The structural equation model supported our hypothesis that CA, PR, PB and PO are crucial predictors of monkeypox prevention behavior for PLWH. In addition, CA indirectly influenced ESB through PO and PR, confirming the mediatory role.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: We would like to thank all participants for their cooperation.

div.head: Funding
div.p: This study was funded by "The Joint Guidance Project of Science and Technology of Qiqihar "in 2022 (NO.LSFGG-2022052).

div.head: Availability of data and materials
div.p: The datasets used and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

div.head: Abbreviations Author Contributions
div.p: Li Qi wrote manuscript. Ronghuang Guo analyzed the data. Lan Yu and Ying Shen distributed and collected questionnaires. Xiaomei Li designed research.

div.head: Ethics approval and consent to participate
Competing interests
div.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
